EVERY LINUX USER WHO NEEDS MS TEAMS NEEDS THIS

It's the Microsoft Teams web app wrapped in an Electron app. It's almost the same as though you were opening it in Chromium. 

It is lighter weight than the official Teams Preview for Linux.

This does not do screen share on Wayland or XOrg, but the official Teams Preview for Linux does, only on XOrg. There are some issues out, but you'll have to look those up on GitHub. Partly an electron issue and partly Microsoft being lazy.
Sharing screen not possible. CPU usage is horrible. Notifications don't show message. Markdown support is TERRIBLE.
summary: Missing features, CPU usage is horrible

summary: Not perfect and yet way better than official client

summary: randomly refreshed and logged me out during a meeting

description:
The official app failed on me today by refusing to detect my audio setup. It's not even like I'm doing anything crazy: we're talking about a pair of airbuds. The app just straight up refuses to detect my audio and my webcam, no matter how many times I restart it and start randomly quitting apps that might also be using audio/webcam. In any case, I start looking for an alternative, and here it is. This version: it. just. works. 

Imagine also my surprise when I discover that this unofficial version also supports background blurring. Maybe I should just stop getting surprised at the low level of effort I can expect from one of the richest corporations on earth.
summary: Choose this one over the official

description: I don't have an organisation (work or school) account. Official app didn't let me in. This one did.
It's also unstable on the odd occasion that it does load.
summary: When attempting to launch the app it simply doesn't load

description:
1. There is no option to prevent microphone auto gain 
2. No notifications at all!
I'm using Plasma Kde on Manjaro

The Official Desktop App for Linux
 is still restricted to business and school accounts. For a personal account only the Web App accessed via a compatible browser is supported. I have found after much effort that it is  possible to get to this via the Official App but it is a tortuous process. This App on opening takes me straight to the web app. Because it is reliant on the web app, this app has reduced functionality compared with the official desktop app but until (if ever) Microsoft gets round to updating the official app I shall continue with this one.
summary: Works for Personal Teams account where Official Linux App does not

description: The official client is missing the ability to blur/change background. This version allows it.

I've used this app for quite some time now. There had often been issues such as black screen on wayland, missing support for background effects, sound device misconfiguration, broken notifications. But for the past couple of months, everything has worked great for me out of the box.

I'm on Fedora 36 with Wayland and Nvidia.
summary: Works great out of the box (for me)

description:
I am using a thinkpad T480s and Fedora 36. 
I was in a teams meeting at work and my 80% battery was drained down to 5% in about 25mins. Looking now its been using an avg of ~80-90% CPU in htop last meeting. Had to stay plugged in to power outlet.
summary: It works, but drains my battery extremely fast

description: Official app for linux is far behind windows version. I was using teams in browser, but this app is more convenient. Works really well, so I definitely recommend it.
This port at least not worse then official and soon to be abandoned client. THX!
Only thing missing is the option to choose automatic starting on boot options, or close to minimize (or to quit), but overall a great implementation! thanks
summary: finally a functioning teams app on linux

I know its a wrapper of the web app but its such a joy to use compared to the preview apps.

thank you!

description: After having tons of problems with microsofts client I've decided to try this one and was shocked that it worked even better than native client on Windows. Everything simply works as it should including screen sharing on Wayland.
It actually works and performs its basic functions

It has background effects! the official one doesn't have it and this one has the same layout I am used to, one weird thing about this is that ms teams detects the os as MacOS, it shows MacOS shortcuts and keyboard layouts, One thing I want to come to this app is an option to make the app fully quit when quitted because it runs in the background and eats my performance, but overall, nice app.
Voice, video, screen share works without problems on Fedora 37, dedicated NVIDIA GPU (proprietary driver)
Better, faster than the MSFT version.
So basically is a LONG shortcut to go to the web app....

Works well on wayland and has working meeting notifications

TBH I was a bit sceptical about how well this app would work but thoses concerns were misplaced. All the AV devices were recognised without any issues and screensharing worked without a hitch. Great work!
summary: Worked flawlessly right out of the box

description: works great, far better than the crappy web app
summary: great work, better than the website

description: Ever since MS only provides Teams as PWA, this is the only viable and working alternative for the desktop.
Great app, thanks.
Thank you devs!

Teams is one of my least favourite applications ever. Its UI is nasty, it's slow and it crashes all the time on Windows. This Flatpak, however, is the most stable instance of Teams I've used. Unlike the Windows version, it is stable and doesn't crash half the time when someone sends you a message or you send a message. I couldn't get Teams to run reliably on any of my Windows machines, but now I have this on my Linux laptop I can reliably communicate with my colleagues. I just wish we didn't have to use Teams at all. But great job on the Flatpak!
summary: The stars are for the Flatpak, not for Teams

description:
Kudos to the maintainer of this project for providing us Linux users victims of corporate greed (MS) with a usable alternative.
Teams on the web will never replace a desktop app, and also Firefox support is terrible. And as we all know, Microsoft doesn't care enough about Linux to release a package for this platform (although they are VERY interested in WSL etc, so "weird").

The maintainer is constantly pushing out updates and is extremely reactive on github. If any bugs are introduced, they are usually fixed very quickly.

Wayland support is also great, and all major features work exactly like on Windows (screen sharing, background blur, etc)

TL;DR: your only valid option for using MS Teams on Linux.
summary: A great package for a subpar MS app

description: Better than tha native win app.Big thank you to the whole project
I am very surprised, everything works as expected. I cant even tell its a web app

Don't get me wrong, I truly despise Teams. The moment I am no longer forced to use it I'll be uninstalling. Until that lovely day however, this version just works. Everything works exactly as jankily and poorly as normal Teams. I have been using this daily for school for a very long time and it has never given me a single issue beyond what can be expected of normal Teams. This is absolutely reliable for professional use of Teams.
summary: Great implementation of an awful app

description:
I haven't tested it much but it seems to be working fine. But on Fedora 39 with proprietary Nvidia drivers for my RTX 3060 this app had many graphical glitches. I fixed them with changing P-state for GPU. 
sudo nvidia-smi --lock-gpu-clocks=2100
sudo nvidia-smi --lock-memory-clocks=7501
With these commands I set high clocks for GPU which resulted in P0 (maximum performance) state. After this, this app worked almost entirely good (although I could see some small and not annoying glitches). Also, glitches in other apps like Chrome and Brave, were fixed. Link to article I used: https://developer.nvidia.com/blog/advanced-api-performance-setstablepowerstate/.
Link to my Medium article on fixing these glitches: https://medium.com/@a.vovchenko01/mitigating-fedora-39-nvidia-glitches-under-wayland-fe830498eb54.
On Arch Linux, using Wayland, the app looks pretty fuzzy, but it accomplishes its purpose and is certainly more functional than the webapp directly in Firefox.
I can run it on Ubuntu 22.04
The teams app is working as expected, but i can't resize the font size. On 1080p, the text is pixelated. Please fix this

Love this app, run it on a virtual desktop that I dedicate to work apps, got a nice systray icon in Gnome desktop, pops up notifications. At the time of writing the only issue I have is the stealing focus on each new notifcation which only started with a recent release around Jan 2024 or maybe December. Otherwise it works great with Fedora 39, Gnome on a Lenovo X1 Gen 11 laptop.
Works very well currently!
Works very well! Thanks

I just want to say that this is a very good MS Teams experience. It supports calls, screen sharing, and everything else.

Also I think opening teams links with the app doesn't work either, it will go to your browser anyways. So you are better off just using the browser.
